The only challenge to this place is to try not to eat the invariably HUGE burrito all in one sitting. I suggest asking for an extra peice of foil when you order so that you can close it up hald way through and eat the rest for lunch the next day.  It's six bucks but two meals.
author: Minx A.

description:
When I'm too hungry for a slice of pesto-potato pizza from Escape From New York, I go to Zona Rosa.

Now, I was born and raised in San Diego, so I have a very particular taste for Mexican food and a "Mission-style" burrito is NOT it.  I would do awful things for an order of 5 rolled tacos for $1.99 or chips/guacamole or a real goddamn carne asada burrito (even though I'm now a vegetarian! They are that good!)  And those hot carrots?  OMG! send me straight to heaven!  Roberto's anyone? http://www.yelp.com/biz/robertos-taco-shop-san-diego-9#hrid:0m13LukfvUEe8og1i_of3g/query:robertos

When I first moved to the Haight, I thought Zona Rosa was just meh.  But it has gotten better (especially since that horrendous practice of steaming tortillas before building burritos stopped taking place!)  The prices are reasonable, though I would gladly pay less for a smaller burrito.  I usually get a vegetarian burrito or a cheese enchilada plate and both are very tasty.

It's too bad they keep getting their alcohol beverage license suspended.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Not a "bad" 1-star, but just not the burrito I'm used to having. Bland, boring and just meh.

I'll do my silver bullet in the Mission, thanks.
author: Charlene L.

description:
This is the best mexican restaurant in SF to me!  I love the burritos (CARNE!) and the service is very friendly, fast, and always consistent!  Fresh chips, GREAT COKE IN THE BOTTLE, and they are clean!  SO TASTY, and the portions are HUGE!  You can probably split a burrito, but I love them so much I finish them when I can! :)  If not, you can always give the rest to one of the starving beggars nearby on Haight.  Great location, great environment, and fun place to grab a quick CHEAP bite! :)
Erica
author: erica Georgia L.

description:
Three and a half stars, technically.

 Being a veggie minded individual, stranded on the haight and desperately craving a burrito... I finally wandered in one afternoon.

Basic ingredients are thankfully animal-free.

I got my $5 burrito and was pleasantly surprised... perhaps because I was expecting it to be worse.... but the salsa is decent, the beans and rice both have a good flavor, and its quick and easy.

EDIT:  So techincally, my rice, bean and lettuce burrito is a mere 3.54.
Boo-ya.
author: Roachie D.

description:
This place has got some good burritos.  It's a "cafeteria-style" place, so I can see them make the burritos on the spot.  It's comforting to see them make the burritos in front of you- the ingredients are fresh and the place is clean.

I got the California burrito- tasted great but the salsa made the burrito a bit soggy.  Good portioned burrito included a handful of chips, but as other people said, it was a bit pricey.

When I went there, they had been prohibited sell alcohol by the California Dept of Alcoholic Beverage Control for selling alcohol to minors, so beer was not a beverage option.
author: Nat R.

description:
Big a%# burritos! 
Expensive, $8. Bring money, cash only.
I usually have a super burrito, with steak or pork. I eat half for lunch and half for dinner. 
Or I get the Zona Rosa taco, which is a small open burrito. Food is good.
Chips are fresh. 
People are nice.
Coke in the glass bottle. Got to love that.
The red sauce is really hot. 
Sometimes pork can be too salty.
author: Melisa O.

description: My vegetable burrito was disgusting. Guacamole is not supposed to be runny. The vegetables were raw and it tasted like a salad wrap more so than a burrito. The chips were so stale! And cash only? This is 2011. Never again.
author: Brittany B.

description: Eating a regular carnitas burrito from here as I type this. i'm a quarter of the way in and i've already finished my whole water bottle. Why? Because this is the saltiest burrito i have EVER had in my life. To the trashcan it goes =(
author: Mo L.

description: In a hurry and need a fast filling bite and nothing else is open? Go here! I did not like the burrito, or the rice or beans. The rice was dry, and the burrito was bland. Overall unfullfilling experience. Yet at the same time filled me up. Go figure, try it, but I pass.
author: Honey B.

description:
I'm from Connecticut, which for many of you may invalidate anything I may have to say about Mexican food. BUT I love Zona Rosa because:

1. I go here on the way home from work when I am having a bad day, and they are always nice to me. 

2. For 6.00 I can stuff my face. And I love to stuff my face.

3. They are cheaper than Balazo's and the decor makes me feel less like I have eaten some bad mushrooms.
author: Caitlin E.

description: Dis place has the best Mexican in San Francisco, hands down.  Very nice staff there also.
author: Eric W.

description: Decent Mexican food in the Upper Haight, where the pickings are slim if you're fixing for a super burrito. Not terrible, but nothing particularly special or extraordinary. I ordered the Super Burrito with carnitas and refried beans. The carnitas itself was a bit dry, but pretty flavorful. The guacamole was the consistency of soup, although there were a few real chunks of avocado interspersed throughout. The pico de gallo was terrible, definitely the worst part of the burrito. Total cost: $9! I don't think I'll be back.
author: Jordan B.

description:
Lots and lots of steak in my steak burrito. Piles of salsa and guacamole in my burrito. Yummy. Two different bottles of hot sauce on each table.

Fast service, not too expensive. Chips are a tiny bit too hard/stale but pretty filling for the price. About $6.50 for a veggie burrito and about $7.50 for a steak burrito. 

The lady behind the cashier was nice and even gave us change for a couple of dollars for the meter. 

The only thing I didn't like was that the tables weren't as clean as I'd like them to be. I had to brush off rice on the chairs before sitting down.
author: Melissa L.

description:
I went here with some friends, and there was a girl with a dog sitting outside asking for money for a burrito. Never saw her by there again. In retrospect, I kind of wish I'd fed her. Maybe someone did...

The food itself is pretty yummy, even if a bit high fat/low sodium for my tastes. They make it all in front of you, which is very considerate of them, although the sight of my food getting put in the mystery oven to get warmed up scares the sh*t out of me.

 Most things come with a generous helping of guacamole, which is awesome. 

Rephrase that - most helpings are absurdly generous. For about $10 you definitely get two full meals.

To my meat- and dairy-eating friends, I recommend the nachos. The mystery oven makes their tortilla chips irresistibly crunchy.

Cash only.
author: Jenny B.

description: This place has high marks so I figured it was in the bag. Wrong. I got a simple Chicken burrito with grilled veggies. The veggies weren't cooked all the way. The burrito itself was pretty bland, not too terrible. The chicken was at least some what good. The tortilla chips were stale. The salsa already on the table was pretty gross. Maybe it was just an off day but I doubt i'll be back any time soon if at all.
author: Cove C.

description: This is always one of my favorite mexican spots to go to when I am on Haight Street. All the workers are really friendly and remember what you like. The food, of course, is always very good and the meat tastes fresh every time. I have never been in here before when they dirty at all. They take very good care of this restaurant. I usually get the super burrito with the red chicken and my mom usually gets the carne asada tacos. I never have a complaint when I'm here.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I used to hate this place.  Prices are definitely higher than other taquerias, and I felt like the burritos were built badly ... portions were off and the burritoes would fall apart because it was too wet.

19 months after my first visit, I'm finding the food has grown on me... I MUST go at least once a week or I get cranky.   Every time I leave, I struggle to control my ever-strengthening urges to steal a squeeze bottle or two of salsa.  The red stuff MUST have crack in it.  So. Damn. Good.
author: Jenny K.

description:
For a place that was once described to me as "the best burrito in San Francisco" I really expected more. Maybe that was my downfall.

It's okay Mexican food. Not the best, not the worst. No matter how much of their salsa they put in your burrito it's not spicy enough for me.

Stay away from the enchiladas and now you'll have to stay away from the beer as they no longer have a license.
author: Allegra F.

description:
Just another day on the haight and normally I avoid buying anything on haight, everything is just too fucking expensive. even the damn thrift stores. but today i was especially hungry so i decided to try out one of the food places. 

i ended up going here, and that was a mistake. first off its like 7 bucks for a regular burrito and then when they're making it they just put everything on it unless you say not to, so it automatically becomes a super burrito which is 9 bucks. then they only take cash, so if you dont have cash you have to use their atm machine which costs another 2 bucks, so now your paying 11 bucks for a burrito that should of cost you 7 in first place. which is still too fucking much. not to mention, the chick at the register was rude.

the burrito itself was decent, but i wont be coming here again.
author: Brian R.

description:
Zona Rosa's is a good restaurant, if you want to eat quickly, and want a filling meal. It serves big portions, and is relatively inexpensive. 
As for the food itself, it is ok, but it's definitely not the best. I would return anytime I'm hungry though.
author: Adam J.

description:
The Carnitas at  Zona Rosa rock!!! I've been coming here since~ 2000 or so when I lived in Corona Heights. The trip was not complete without picking up a few used CDs at Amoeba and checking out the goods at Giant Robot. I make the same trip - but coming up from the Western Ed / NOPA now.

I am always amazed how the women behind the counter can scoop up beans with the perforated spoon, shake them just so...so as not to drip pinto bean juice in the black beans. The ladies here have been here as long as I've been thowing down for some Pork.
author: masugu m.

description:
I wish you could still do 1/2 stars cause it woulda been three and a half.

The only have one kind of tortilla for the burritos, it is the large Oaxacan style meaning thin, white flour, heavy on the shortening. But, the large size does mean it can wrap up all the bountiful ingredients. 

There is a veggie and a vegetarian burrito option. The veggie comes with 4 or 5 nicely roasted plant friends and the vegetarian is just the bean and rice, salsa cruda &guac basic, no frills. 

I opted for the no frills to keep it under $7 and was very satisfied. Big enough that I had to take my burrito butt home with me for lunch today. Chips are the hard super crunchy kind, but are very greasy. Salsa comes in old fashioned ketchup bottles on every table, it is good, but to be honest isn't probably homemade. Guac looks like it might come out of a 5# bag as well. 

SO~ not exactly the epitome of fresh, but it is very FAST, they stay friendly despite all the states of their customers, and the ingredients are recently prepared, not sitting all day. 

If your burrito butt refers to the back of your pants, you won't be disappointed.
author: Miel H.

description: Decent burritos that are WAY overpriced.
author: Andrew K.

description: The first time I visited Zona Rosa was about 6 years ago and I was very impressed with their "Super Burrito".  6 years later, this place still makes some fantastic burritos.  Keep in mind that this is a pretty bare bones taqueria and the options are a bit limited, the good things are very good. Try the burritos and quesadillas.  They have specials like chimichangas and tamales, which are also good, but stay away from the enchiladas since they aren't really cooked the way once would normally expect them to be cooked (microwave).  They just lost their liquor license so no more beer, but you can still order Mexican sodas.  Enjoy!
author: Ken G.

description:
Decent burritos, chips are usually fresh, and the hot sauce is YUMMY! 

I'm a really picky eater (it's taken me YEARS to actually admit to it, so don't hate, PLEASE..) and I usually custom-make my burritos. When it really comes down to it, it's a veggie, which is pretty hard to mess up but you never know, the rice might be hard, beans cold, lettuce soggy.. 

But nope! Not here! They aim to please, and it actually comforts me to know they never get below a 90 on their inspection score. 

(I'm a score whore)
author: Michelle R.

description: I want so much to like a taqueria in my neighborhood, but El Balazo and Zona Rosa just don't cut it. More than average prices, less than average quality. Also out of red sauce last time I went there.
author: Travis H.

description: Yum!  Great burrito, good beans. The big guy at the counter is really cool & friendly.  Great for quick, cheap eats.
author: Amy T.

description: My favorite burritos in SF come from Farolito and Cancun, but if you're on Haight Zona Rosa gets the job done.  Good, cheap and fast - and they have squirt bottles of salsa on the tables.  So much better than little plastic containers!
author: Allison D.

description:
Okay burritos, not even close to competing for best burrito in the city. Also, as others have noted, it's pretty expensive.  

Not much seating room and their chips are always stale and cold and feel like eating tree bark.
author: Derek M.

description:
Great value...  so much better than Balazo down the street...

Pollo Verde is not very good though and it's a somewhat grimey place...
author: Alexander T.

description:
This place is pretty good.

First of all , the chips are damn good. Nice and fresh and greasy, my favorite!

The vegetarian burrito comes jam packed with goodness, guacamole and all.  The burritos are huge and all for $6.00. 

The hot sauce is good too, just enough of a kick.
author: Chili B.

description:
The burrito is good but not great and for being in California I think we should only have great.

Also, the cash only thing kills me, especially when the burritos are close to TEN DOLLARS!?  Yeah, eh...i dont know.  Tasted good, but i would not go back i dont think

Speaking of CASH ONLY, what's up with that? i mean, shady..no?  I get it that they don't want the charges Visa and folks charge, but think about how much more business you would do if you were not turning away people with no cash on them...hmm.
author: Noah b.

description: Bland and few choices, and every order comes with a free cup of grease! If there was a Taco Bell next door, I would go there. In fact, there are better burrito joints down the street. I'm just sayin'...
author: Edmund C.

description: super stingy and shady. they are cash only so after i told them my order before handing them the cash, I asked if I could use the restroom. their only response was, " You have to pay FIRST". aren't we rude? either way I learned a lesson with haight st. ALWAYS skip the restroom around haight. tiny, unsanitary and not one spot on the wall free of graffitti.
author: Jessica T.

description: Dry tamale. Not so great enchilada. Rodrigo loved his super burrito lol
author: Kevin S.

description: Ate this for lunch very often, not the best burrito in SF but it will do in a pinch.  The Veggie burrito is a reliable bet.
author: Jen H.

description:
PROS: Burritos are delicious, fast service, great location, interior.

CONS: Overpriced, cash only, kind of rude lady behind counter.
author: Robert P.

description: I hadn't been here in yeeears until recently and - hot damn! - that's a good burrito. Carne asada was tender, flavorful and perfectly cooked; beans are also well cooked and in no way bland but not too salty; and the hot sauce here is spicy and yummy. If I lived any closer to this place, I'd try to work it into my taqueria rotation, but I'll definitely return when shopping in the Upper Haight next.
author: Kristina A.

description:
you got me hooked.
this place is my like a drug. it satisfy my cravings for their super delicious burrito and i refuse to try another place.

went to haight yesterday from daly city just so i can have my burrito.
ended up watching spain win the world cup. whooooo!

it was a perfect combo.

& i'm addicted.
author: Anna P.

description:
Perhaps because I lived in the upper Haight, and then next to GGPark, on the north side, I came to love this place for it's proximity. But no, Taqueria Balazo and the Citrus Cafe were right there, too. And yet, neither of those rank among my favorites.

ZR's burritos are big, quickly made and, OK, perhaps a buck pricier. But I gladly paid it for the al pastor, pollo verde or the BBQ pork. If you get the carnitas, be prepared for huge chunks - and that's no complaint.

Not once did I ask for a "super" ... "regular" was always more than enough. And that's saying something ...
author: Mike p.

description: Best burrito in the city.  Easy, fast, cheap and delicious.  No frills, but hands down my go to spot.  Cash only.
author: Betsy C.

description: This is a great place to get a tasty bite to eat, especially before or after you visit Amoeba Records just down the block toward the park.  I like the vegetarian burrito and vegetable burrito, good size, good price and comes with chips.  I also love that they have big squezze bottles of red and green hot sauce on each table . . . I like to squirt as I go.  The people have always been friendly and it is fun to sit at the counter and people watch as you munch.
author: D. J.

description: This is Mexican food for white people--mainly white college aged hipsters. Its cheap, you get a big burrito, and possibly a day on the toilet. The staff is not so friendly, but if you had to deal with stupid gringo youth all day you'd be rude too. There are a millions Mexican restaurants in San francisco explore you will find better than this. I think this place makes a living off of the drunks out of the near by bars who don't realize what their eating until its to late.
author: Johnny B.

description:
Perhaps not the best taqueria in town (look to the Mission district for those), but definitely the best in the Haight. Nothing hit the spot better than a burrito from Zona Rosa on the afternoon after the night before, if you get what I'm sayin'. If you're a meat eater, the meat was always delicious, chargrilled and tender. If not, the beans they use (you can select what type) were always so flavourful the veg option was just as delicious.


 The prices are brilliant, and I really cannot see how you'd do better than to grab one of their huge burritos for a filling and cheap lunch.
author: Laurelei

description:
This review is all about the Super Carnitas Burrito. If you like a huge handful of melt-in-your-mouth greasy pork that's grilled right before it is enveloped in your tortilla, this is the source. 

It also adds tot he flavor if you get extra onions and cilantro and an unusual request, but always honored, is half black and half refried beans (to give just the right flavor and texture). Add on sour cream, cheese, gauc, salsa and jalapenos and you have a delicious and very filling meal (cut in half and you have lunch for the next day). 

Their chips are great, fresh, substantial not to greasy but good corn flavor and their red and green salsa sauces are perfect. 

The counter where the food is preped remains immaculately clean (which is the fith star in my review). 

True the platters leave something to be desired - head down the street to El Balazo for those. But if the words pork and burrito make your head spin give these a try.
author: Dave P.

description:
Though Mikey did like his burrito (veggie), it does not come close to the veggie burritos (or any burritos for that matter) at El Farolito's.  However, he was impressed with how great the guacamole and chipotle sauce were.  He usually doesn't go for chipotle.  So in his opinion, Zona Rosa is pretty good for condiments.  No tortas... what a dissapointment.

Stephie had her first horchata (she had been putting it off since the age of 15) and thought it was too sweet.  Mikey thought it was perfect.  He has more horchata experience than her.  This horchata, he says, was not pasty at all.

We give it a 3!
author: Steph and Mike A.

description: I was not too impressed.  I kept being told that I can't leave SF without trying some Mexican food there.  So I stopped into this place and the food was alright.  Here in Detroit we have a sizeable community of Mexicans in the southwest part of the city and I have to say that we have some pretty great Mexican restaurants and taquerías.  I didn't realize how good it was until now.  I am sure there are other very good Mexican restaurants in SF but this was just an okay one.
author: Ebony T.

description:
Try the wet burrito. It'll leave you with such a wet and messy facial that you'll wonder if the burrito enjoyed it more.

Very decent food prepared well, and at decent portions.

They dont have a salsa bar at all which makes or breaks these burrito joints, but the guy did give me a massive mound of jalapeno's on request.

Worth checking out if you're in the area and aren't wearing a white shirt.
author: Tam X.

description: The tacos here were pricey and inauthentic (all this beans and shit shouldn't be on a taco). I was just generally unimpressed. Their agua fresca was really good though.
author: Shauna T.

description: I love this place and have been coming for YEARS!!! I think it's because the staff is so cool and always remember what I order down to my drink! I often get the enchilada plate w/ re-fried beans, salad and chips & salsa  Im never disappointed! The staff rocks and its always clean, foods pretty reasonable and if you see a homeless person or two outside what did you expect?? Its the haight!
author: Rae W.

description: I spend about three days a week within a stones throw of the City's best place to get a burrito con frijoles (refried beans).  Try the spicy steak burrito with just frijoles, rice, & cheese, with no salsa and a side of sour cream.  Oh, and have them nuke a chimichanga to start with; and don't forget your Coca Cola hecho en Mexico!!!
author: Tudor J.

description:
I eat here all the time, I live right around the corner.
Get the burritos, ingredients are always fresh, as good as anything in the Mission.
Chile rellenos and the tamales are also good.

I can recommend the agua frescas too.

The only reason it gets 4 stars is because they keep losing their liquor license, so you can't buy a Pacifico or a Negro Modelo to wash the food down with anymore.
author: Geordie V.

description: This classic San Francisco taqueria is my favorite neighborhood burrito joint and if you eat in, you may be lucky enough to spy - or even dine with- some of San Francisco's finest punks, hippies, street kids, skaters, gothics and other assorted homeless freakasauruses.  This place stocks a large number of fresh ingredients which you are welcome to simply point to and have added to your burrito as you move from right to left across the open service counter.  Another feature of this place is they charbroil their meats, whereas many taquerias merely fry and/or simmer their meats and then fork them. The quality is good and quite reliable, and their prices modest.  Parking is nearly impossible, though, and I will say that I have had a couple of recent unsavory run-ins with a fatty chicken or two.  All the more reason to try the California burrito with carnitas. Overall it is very good.  Excellent quesadillas and tacos too. Bring cash as they don't take credit.
author: Rick H.

description:
god, i love good mexican food. and man, i love it when things are fried just right.

here, they are fried just right. and they are mexican.

winning combination!!
author: Irene S.

description: I really like the food here! I love their burritos and tacos along with their chips! Great place to go eat after a long day of shopping! Yum!
author: Mel P.

description: Not as amazing as Burrito Real on Rengstorff Ave. in Mountain View, but that's 50 miles away.  Solid, reliable, and a zona rosa burrito is always the first urge I have when I am super hungry and looking to get "laid out" by the hugest burrito imaginable.  The beans and rice are always fresh, the meat hearty and flavorful, and the guacamole is superior to the freakily neon-green stuff they have at Balazo.  The staff is very nice and they'll take a dollar off the total price if you flash a student I.D.  The chips are by far the greasiest and most satisfying burrito joint chips in S.F., but you might ruin your appetite so go easy on those bad boys.   A burrito there is the size of a tire iron and will keep you satisfied for about 6-8 hours.   I rank it over Balazo for the superior quality of the carne asada and guacamole.
author: Dan L.

description: Another taqueria on Haight that delivers a burrito with terrible service every time.  If you think of the word 'surly', the employees of Zona Rosa should come to mind.  They definitely make a better burrito than their angry brethren at El Balazo down the street though, so I prefer the Zona. I really with I could just make it to the Mission on my lunch break for a better food coma-inducing burrito...
author: Craig E.

description: A pricey but excellent burrito. This was my regular burrito destination when I lived in this part of town. You can find'em like this in LA anywhere.
author: Scott M.

description: I live around the corner from Zona Rosa and it's often our go-to spot for dinner when we don't want to cook. Good burritos. Big enough too that we share one between the two of us. Yum.
author: Gerry B.

description: Had a decent veggie burrito here.  But the prices are bit high compared to other places.
author: Ed M.

description: Pretty decent burritos....nothing thrilling, and they use too much cilantro, but they are decent, and huge for the price.
author: Barbs J.

description: I agree with Cactus, excellent burritos.  They are huge and made to order.  The guac is spectaular too.  It can feel a bit dodgy in there so you minus one star for the decor.  Cheap and quality food my favorite combo!
author: Chris W J.

description:
Zona rosa makes a solid burrito or quesadilla.  Not nearly as good as a mission burrito, but it'll get the job done. 

Their best meat is by far the carnitas, its pretty much the only one I get.

if you're in the upper Haight and need a burrito I'd go here over El Balasio.  The atmosphere is a little nicer, and unlike Haight's other burrito joint, i've never gotten food poisoning here.
author: Brett L.

description: I love their vegetarian tacos-- they are a great value and quite tasty.  I always stop by when I am in the Haight.  Also, they have excellent frescas.  I try to sit in the corner window when I come-- makes for some fabulous people-watching.
author: Nicci S.

description: I have a soft spot for Zona Rosa - burritos from their Berkeley location were a staple during my college days.  On a recent trip to the Haight I stopped by the SF location for a burrito.  They are still very decent burritos, and the window bars are good for people watching.  Just make sure there isn't a crazy guy in front of yours before you sit down.
author: Sara M.

description: The best burrito that the Haight has to offer (with all due respect to Haight denizens who prefer Balazo). $6 for a regular burrito. Superfy-it for an extra buck and you'll get guac and cheese. Not the best burrito you'll ever have, but you'll be satisfied and ready to continue your shopping spree at Amoeba, True, Kid Robot, etc., etc.
author: Nishan K.

description: Best burrito in the Haight hands down- Clean, friendly service and Gigantic burritos. We go once a week for the veggie burrito and if were super hungry we throw in a pork tamale.
author: Maijken G.

description: Zona Rosa you have gone downhill. I remember in 2001, when i went to USF, your burrittos were all i could think about. Now whenever i do end up eating at your establishment, I end up wishing for a mulligan. Wake up Zona Rosa and please realize 6.50 for a medicore vege burrito that makes your patrons ill is lame and change that shit up.
author: Justin W.

description: My review is based on the one time I went here and got  a combo choose 2 items plate. I chose the veggie taco and the cheese enchilada.  The enchilada was pathetic. I saw the guy "make" it. He put cheese in a tortilla, wrapped it up, put some sauce on it and threw it in the broiler for about 2 minutes. What came out was exactly what went in only the cheese on the outside was melted. The inside cheese was still cold and not melted at all. I have an idea... if you have enchiladas on the menu then maybe you should actually make enchiladas!  The veggie taco was certainly nothing to scream about either. The boyfriend's quesadilla was prepared the same way as my enchilada.  Maybe their burritos are better, I'll never find out.
author: michelle h.

description:
I like this place and El Balazo.  

This place rules for chicken nachos.  
if you want a burrito or taco, i go to El Balazo.

Overall, I feel they use a good quality of meat (which is key for restaurants like this)
Restaurant is on the smaller side so this place is better for take-out.
author: WP D.

description: Does it compare to the Mission? Of course not. But it'd do when the line to Cha Cha Cha is too long. Had the chimichunga plate today and it was just slightly spicy which was perfect for me. The guacamole wasn't bad.
author: Linda L.

description:
When I lived in the Haight, I probably went to Zona Rosa every other day.  No lie.  I also weighed about 20 lbs more than I weigh now.  Go figure.  So the other day when Clams and Mellaw and myself were getting schnockered at Murios (well, I was already hammered after going to Bacchus by myself then Zeitgeist), I was really hungry and needed some assfire.  Now, folks, let's not take this the wrong way.  When I say assfire, I literally mean assfire.  I love spicy food and eat it a lot, but Zona Rosa does something to their red hot sauce that makes my ass sing like a canary at high noon.  The red hot sauce goes down well, sits well, but then KABOOM!  Hiroshima's got nothing compared to the assfire Zona Rosa drops on me.  
Normally I don't really care if Spazz Roomie or anybody encounters the ass fire, but this time...good lord...I actually apologized BEFORE ignition for the cacophony that I knew was about to ensue.  And I swear, if this Jewish boy didn't get down on his knees like a good Catholic and praise the lord for letting me survive.  Then again, I think I'll be back there in a few days cuz it's so f'ing good and once you've had a taste...it's hard to stop.
author: Zev K.

description: Big stuffed burritos although not as tasty as others I've had. Zona Rosa's done me okay when I've stumbled out of Amoeba with a suffering bank balance - but they're not as cheap as they used to be, and I'd rather chow in the Mission.
author: Robbie G.

description: I've just had veggie burritos here and while they're not terrible, they're not good either.  There are better spots to eat at.
author: Rachel N.

description:
kinda boring, actually.
and way more expensive than papalotes, which is a 10 minute walk away, but oh so worth it.
on the few times i've been too lazy to wlak for a decent burrito, i've always been dissapointed with the zona rosa burritos, there always seems to be unidentifiable objects in the beans.
blech. no thanks.
author: Melody O.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by how much I liked my burrito. The carnitas was great and the refried beans were awesome. It hit the spot and was fairly large. I wish they would take card, cash only places are so not convenient. I will definitely go back when I'm in the neighborhood and craving a burrito.
author: Bryan S.

description: Only eat here if you have a gun to your head. I'd rather barf up something then eat it instead. That is just an example of how bad it is.
author: James J.

description:
this was a pretty terrible burrito experience...  enough so to make me create a yelp profile just so i could warn other people off who might find themselves trapped in the haight and hoping to find a good burrito (my ultimate verdict is: fat chance).

-1 star : no salsa choice, and the salsa they did have was basically just a chopped tomato.  no peppers, little onion, little deliciousness...

-1 star : the woman ignored me when i said no guacamole.  she also ignored the next person in line saying "no cheese"...it wasn't just me.

-1 star : no salsa bar to accompany the chips, and they weren't good enough to stand up on their own.  they were overly greasy, too.

-1 star :  just because.  yuck!  i'd never eat here again.
author: Steve v.

description:
Pretty good burritos.  I got a simple veggie burrito, and I wont complain about the price (even though my fave place gives me the same size 'ritto for almost 2 bucks less and is in Piedmont).

I will just say that I liked the food, the guacamole, everything  

Don't dig on the sauces being left out.  I'm always afraid I'm getting a spit/jizz bottle of green sauce, ya know?
author: M. M.

description: Very overpriced burritos that just aren't all that. If you want a burrito, go to the Mission.
author: Don H.

description: While working at a local yoga studio in the area, I was desperate for some Mexican food. After going to Balazo and being very disappointed, I figured I'd try here. It's ok, if you are having a serious Mexi-craving, but it reminded me too much of Taco Bell.
author: Victoria K.

description:
it's a decent place for a taqueria that's not in the mission... i like it best from the ones that are on haight.  the place is relatively clean and the food seems to be also... 
tasty food, but a bit pricier than the average mission taqueria...
author: charlotte s.

description:
went here with chubber chubby chub with his pubes shaved.

we ate a burrito. i had the carne asada i believe. and it was pretty damn good i have to say. it was pretty damn crowded there when we went.
author: Victor B.

description: The food here is great... Everything is worth a try... The atmosphere is hilarious... It's neatly decorated but the clientele? Wow... Can be very entertaining at times.... And the food is a little expensive as taquerias go... Lately, when I want burritos or taqueria food on Haight I go to El Balazo...
author: Lindsey S.

description: I often visited Zona Rosa's when I got tired of eating of Taco Bell at USF.  The portions are huge and always had leftovers to take back to eat for a later time.  The steak burrito was my favorite.
author: Trish P.

description: Yelp is funny. Six months ago, ZR had half the rating of Balazo across the street, and I was all "whaaa?" But now it's got four stars, the acknowledgement it deserves as a very good SF taqueria. They make a great burrito (I eat the veggie and bean/cheese), the chips are always fresh and awesome (the thing they do better than my favorite taqueria, Cancun), and it's average cost. So four stars for this Haight St classic.
author: jack p.

description: There are just times you get a hankerin' for a burrito that is slapped together in under 5 seconds. At such times, I do not expect an "experience" nor do I expect culinary perfection. I expect a big damn burrito at a reasonable, no, a cheap price. And Zona Rosa cranks out relatively cheap and wolfable burritos. What more do you want or expect from this kind of joint? Bonus points on my veggie burrito for "mashing" the ingredients together (good mix w/ every bite) and for the very tight wrap making utensils unnecessary. Do be prepared to sometimes wade through Gutter Punks begging for change or grub or just cluttering the corner. I think may an overflow parking area for them when it is too crowded in front of Amoeba and/or McDonald's.
author: Don B.

description: Should be a 3.5 stars.  This place has pretty good burritos.  The rice is well seasoned and tasty.  The grilled chicken is good also, tender and flavorful. With a lot of competition in the area (Chabella's and Balazo's), Zona Rosa is the most expensive, in my opinion tastes the best.  So I guess the trade off is worth it.
author: Shane Y.

description:
The food is good. BUT, carne asada is very dry, the wonderful green sauce is perfect some days, extremely hot some other days and I love spicy food.
My main objection is that the servers preparing the food to serve use their bare hands to handle and dip into the food without gloves. The bathroom is truly dreadful.
This makes me a little afraid of the sanitary standards of this restaurant.
author: Yasmine S.

description: I'm pretty critical of burritos. Taco Del Mar in Seattle has an amazing burrito that I'd say is my 5 star 'yardstick by which awesomeness is measured' when it comes to burritos. Zona Rosa was pretty good. However, I would add another star on if I could have served myself up some salsa for my chips. They were just nekked, and the sauce squeezers on the tables didn't quite cut it like some pico de gallo would have.
author: Will L.

description: My favorite burrito spot on Haight Street.  Sure it isn't the most popular, but it's reliable and sometimes you want to know what to expect.
author: T-Bone L.

description: I used to come here all the time when I lived in the Haight.  Now that I live further out, I still make special trips for the chicken burrito.  This place is definitely a diet buster but well worth the instant gratification you feel.
author: Adam O.

description: OK burrito's, a good bang for your buck cuz they're HUGE and pretty cheap - nothing amazing
author: Jared F.

description: I used to get the veggie burritos from here all the time when I lived in the neighborhood. I haven't been there in a while, but their super burritos used to be the size of a small baby.
author: Evelyn G.

description: Great tasting tacos on Haight. Not the most high quality food or enticing atmosphere, but cheap, easy, good tasting and clean.  $4.00 for a huge plate of tacos, can't beat that!
author: Amanda L.

description: Now that is what I call a burrito! Zona Rosa used to be a favorite ten years ago when I lived in SF. I particularly remember it being fantastic food for a mild hang over. Super Burrito to go and a walk into the park on Sunday afternoon is the best in life. I was lucky enough to go there this trip to SF and the walk down memory lane was great. It hasn't changed a bit. I don't understand why we can't get Mexican food like this in Chicago. Just about every burrito in Chicago comes with loads of shredded lettuce and no cilantro. It's just a damn shame. Zona Rosa, please open a Midwest location.
author: Andy R.

description: I thought this place hit the spot, but I'd rather not pay 8+ bucks for a burrito... especially since the one I ordered looked pretty minimal (the California burrito, I think it was called). I would most likely not come back, but if I was craving a burrito and happened to be in the Haight, I'd probably go here unless someone else has a better suggestion.
author: Caroline L.

description: They fed me for a year.  Would get 4 stars if they didn't jack up their prices.  Maybe they're just trying to keep the Haight riff-raff out of their chic establishment.  I've always liked their rice.
author: Jackson R.

description:
good burritos/nachos, not the best ever.
but super good for the 'hood.

take-out, with extra cilantro, please!
author: Ge O.

description: Good grilled steak. Tender, nice char flavor, not too greasy. Mix it with some gooey, flavorful refried beans, plenty of guac and tomatoes, onions, cilantro, and the yummy red OR green salsa (both really excellent) in an ultra-crispy fried taco shell and I am a happy girl. Good burritos, too. Definitely not the best in the city, but quite possibly the best in the area. We used to have to go to Pancho's if we wanted taqueria Mexican without getting in the car. It is definitely worth the extra few blocks for Zona Rosa.
author: Veronica L.

description: Home of the "hippie burrito," yet there's much more! It's one of the only places I've found that has homemade crunchy tacos. When you fill one with their green chile chicken and the other with carnitas you're in for a delight (don't forget to ask them to add cilantro)... the combo plate comes with rice and beans. All the food is very fresh and tasty. It's not Mission-Style but holds its own in every way. The red picante is better than the green but my only complaint is they do not have a tomatillo salsa. Vaya con luz y amor
author: David S.

description: Yummy yummy in my tummy. I love their veggie burrito. Not the best I've ever had but pretty damn good. Plus you get a rad discount if you work on the street. Cash only, which sucks, but the workers are super duper nice.
author: melody r.

description: I've been going to Zona Rosa for over five years, and I've always been greeted with a warm smile. Not only is the food delicious but the crew (Vero, Alex, Pepe, Ignacio) are awesome!
author: Veronica B.

description: I would have to agree totally with abl.  This place isn't the best Mexican restaurant in town, but its a consistent, friendly, cheap and easy substitute for the $3 slice of pizza @ Escape from NY.  In my book  that merits 4 picante taco con jalapeno stars.  Plus their horchata is really yummy too.
author: Maz N.

description:
Her: Can I help you?

Me: Veggie burrito please.

Her: Type of beans?

Me: Black.

Her: Everything on it? Salsa, guacamole, cheese?

Me: Yes. Lettuce and jalapenos too.

Her: For here or to go?

Me: Here. Can I have a water cup too please?

Her: Certainly. $5.70 please.

Me: Here you go. Thank you very much.

I sit either at one of the tables or at the window looking at Haight... Green salsa in hand. That's the way it's always been. That's the way it will always stay. Best burrito in town.
author: Adam S.

description: Most underrated taqueria?  Perhaps, perhaps not.  But it is my neighborhood staple, the oft-overlooked jewel of the usually overpriced Haight St mexican restaurant genre.  I must add that they are particularly good for nachos as they have thick, crunchy, fresh chips.  And they have something wicked going on with that chipotle salsa...they give it away and it's MAGICAL.  Take a Papalote lover there.  The red salsa is that good.
author: sheena b.

description: I've been here off and on for years. They have a convenient locale by Amoeba, which is the only reason to be on that street in my opinion. The food is kind of bland, but hits the spot. Don't expect much seating and the service is not with a smile.
author: Russell S.

description: The San Francisco-style burritos are quite flavorful here. I like the help-yourself red and green (tomatillo) hot sauce bottles, which I keep on heaping on the tasty burritos and tortilla chips.
author: Daisuke K.

description:
Although I have not been here recently, I have been going to this place since 2002 for more than 10 times. 
The food has been consistently good and very flavorful.
The regular taco is good. The carnitas burrito is good also.
The tamale is good also.
The red sauce and the green tomatillo sauce are spicy but awesome!
Sure, the price runs a little on the high side.
I usually keep pouring and pouring them into my plate.
This location is located near Amoeba music store and as Rick H. mentioned, there are a lot of punks, street kids, gothics, and homeless people - and if you pick the table next to the window, you can watch the people with interesting outfit passing by.
Oh, one negative is that they only accept cash and parking is hard to find (I am actually annoyed with places that only accept cash especially if parking is not easy to find), but I can not take out any of the star because their food overcome anything else.
author: Oribel ..

description: This is by far my favorite mexican restaurant in the city! It is so bomb, I could seriously eat here everyday - and I have. I love sitting by the window and watching the people walk by. They have such good spicy beef and the chips are hella good too. Also I like how they have the old fashioned coke bottles.
author: Lacey P.

description: Came here after some drinking during the Pats game. I had a zona rosa taco which had a ton of stuff on it, I couldn't fitt all of it in the two corn tortillas they give you. But luckily they give you chips to scoop up the straglers. The burritos were f-ing huge. The staff was friendly and quick.
author: Ryan M.

description: The best mexican food in the upper haight is not necessarily the best mexican food in the city.  If you want a pretty good veggie taco or an alright veggie burrito, go here.  If not, and you're stuck on haight, you're shit out of luck.
author: Veronica B.

description: Love their crunchy tacos and veggie tamales.  Portions are generous.  Almost always my default choice for good eats.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Good food, short lines, and not too expensive.  Its either this or Cha Cha Cha when on Haight...
author: John D.

description:
Zona Rosa is like an old friend.  The burritos are great, not as good as the Mission, but very good for this part of town.  The rolling technique, in particular, is excellent here, as you get a burrito with superb structural integrity.  They've got two kinds of hot sauces -- both good -- and they give you free chips.  You can get anything you want here when it comes to beans, meats, tortillas.  The grilled chicken is awesome and not just burned to a crisp like a lot of places.

Cons: Not open late, don't take credit card, meat sits out too long.
author: Dean A.

description: Lame selection. Mediocre food. Friendly service. Clean restaurant. There are many better options in the city, but not in the hood.
author: Joe C.

description: We moved away  from San Francisco and a grilled chicken zone rosa burrito is the singlemost craving I have.  I think the cost has gone up a lot and the burrito quality down a bit in the past couple of years but it is still one of the best things going.
author: Max S.

description: Oh my God, I'm dying right now. I've been going to Zona Rosa for FIFTEEN YEARS! The food has always done me right...until yesterday. That was the day I decided to try their camarones for the first time ever. Big mistake. I have been up since 4am blowing chunks...out of my ass. Sorry for the graphic details, but seriously, I must warn you: do not order the shrimp burrito, no matter how tasty it sounds. It was sooo good going in, but it didn't feel so nice coming out. To top it all off, tomorrow is my birthday and I can't even celebrate to the maximum because my tummy is in a die hard battle with my colon. So, why three stars you say? Come on, I've been going there since I was 6 or 7 and everything has always been fantastic - the chicken, the beef, the pork, the tamales, the guacamole, everything! So I can't deny those fifteen years of bliss, but this one experience might have done me in...
author: Lizzy C.

description: Deserves more than 3, not quite 4 stars.  For what it is, the food is pretty good.  It does not rate with the average strip mall taco joints in San Diego, but much better that balazo down the street.
author: Robb K.

description: Zona Rosa has my favorite burrito in SF.  The super chicken verde makes my soul sing.  I also really enjoy the salsa verde in the bottles on the tables, as it isn't afraid to be spicy.  The window seating is perfect for people watching on haight.  The staff are always friendly, the food is consistently good, and besides the extra buck you pay for eating a burrito on haight street, I would recommend this place to anyone looking for a damn fine burrito.
author: Trey d.

description: This place gave my food poisoning, it looked to fresh (but clearly wasn't) but tasted hellove average
author: Teresa G.

description: not bad. if im in the upper haight looking for a burrito i generally go here. a bit less crowded than el balazo.
author: Andrew D.

description: On the one hand Zona Rosa is located in a great spot and their food is reasonably good.  I have eaten there many times.  On the other hand I got food poisoning one of those times.  That was the last time I ate there.  You pays your money and you takes your chances-- out of all the burritos I've had all over the place I've only had food poisoning from 2 places in the city though (the other was El Toro)
author: Bruce S.

description: Once I watched a Subway Sandwich Artist (TM) assemble a chicken sub without ever looking down to see his creation, yielding something which only resembled a sandwich in the most abstract form.  This was in New Haven, where the food service industry prides itself on hiring employees who work with less gusto and care than anywhere else in the country.  My visit to Zona Rosa yesterday made me think for a moment that I'd somehow been transported back to gloomy New Haven.  The ingredients sat uncovered behind the counter, assumably a purposeful decision by the management to help maintain a lukewarm temperature perfect for breeding bacteria and serving up unsatisfying burritos.  The staff were clearly unconcerned with what they were preparing of service with a smile.  The burritos were overpriced, the chips were greasy and cold, and there was no salsa bar.   I'd go back here if I were starving, every other place in the Haight was closed, and I wanted salmonella.
author: Charles C.

description: bo-ring and just average tasting food, too. go to balazo, instead.
author: Bee H.

description: It wasn't the best burrito in town and the location isn't the prime, but you get a cheap big burrito for under $10.
author: Nora D.

description: this place is quite good. not exploding deliciousness, but brimming deliciousness. you eat there. they say carnitas best in city. and don't forget your jarritos. by the way, it's not grimy. relative to other taquerias, this place is clorox fresh!
author: Sue K.

description: really yummy burritos, fast service, cheap price.  the salsa verde is spicy & delicious!
author: cc r.

description: the quesadilla suiza with carnitas is not to be believed. with the accoutrements, it is the perfect balance of succulence, chewiness, freshness, crispness. i love this place even more than the mission joints. INCREDIBLE food.
author: UrbanEmpress G.

description: This is one of my favorite burrito places in the city. Yes, it is overpriced and yes, they are constantly getting their liquor license revoked but their burritos and nachos both are awesome. Just be prepared for bad parking, panhandlers and cash only.
author: Jody D.

description: The food is lackluster, and I don't understand how they can get a good health rating when the food sits cold or lukewarm in the steam tables for so long. I quit going there when I saw how the homeless use this place as their own personal kitchen: grabbing empty cups from the garbage can outside and coming in to fill them up with soda, in full view of the staff; or, even better, bringing in two fully-sealed microwave popcorn bags and getting the staff to open them and pop them one at a time in their microwave. I didn't stay around to see if the staff washed their hands after handling the popcorn bags. They also can't hold on to their liquor license.
author: Arthur B.
